wander.translation[0].definitions[0].def: to walk slowly across or around an area, usually without a clear direction or purpose
wander.translation[0].definitions[0].exa: He was found wandering the streets of New York.
I’ll wander around the mall for half an hour.
She wandered aimlessly about the house.
Ana wandered off to get a drink.
wander.translation[0].definitions[1].def: to walk away from where you are supposed to stay
wander.translation[0].definitions[1].exa: Don’t let any of the kids wander off.
wander.translation[0].definitions[2].def: if your mind, thoughts etc wander, you no longer pay attention to something, especially because you are bored or worried
wander.translation[0].definitions[2].exa: Mrs Snell’s mind wandered and the voices went on and on.
wander.translation[0].definitions[3].def: to start to talk about something not related to the main subject that you were talking about before
wander.translation[0].definitions[3].exa: Pauline started to wander from the point.
wander.translation[0].definitions[4].def: if your eyes or your gaze wander, you look around slowly at different things or at all parts of something
wander.translation[0].definitions[4].exa: His gaze wandered round the room.
wander.translation[0].definitions[5].def: if a road or a river wanders somewhere, it does not go straight but in curves
wander.translation[0].definitions[5].exa: The Missouri River wanders across several states.
wander.translation[0].definitions[6].def: if a man’s hands wander, he touches the body of a woman he is with, especially where she does not want him to
wander.translation[0].definitions[6].exa: Be careful, he’s got wandering hands.
wander.translation[1].definitions[0].exa: I had a bit of a wander round the shops.
